oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pharmacology Teaching Laboratories: Use of Animals and/or Information Technologies
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Aronson, Arthur L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: information technology
pharmacology laboratory sessions
computer simulations
veterinary students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The question of using animals and/or information technologies in pharmacology teaching laboratories was something that we had to deal with in our department earlier this year when our highly talented teaching laboratory technician resigned to accept another position. We are one of the twenty-three of thirty colleges of veterinary medicine in the U.S. and Canada surveyed by Charles R. Short and Carl E. Aronson in 1985 and 1986 (1-3) using animals in pharmacology laboratory sessions for veterinary students. We also are one of the twenty-five institutions that utilize video tapes of demonstration experiments, at least occasionally. However, we have not yet utilized computer simulations in our teaching program. Only four of thirty institutions reported using computers in teaching pharmacology to veterinary students.
